body:
@dasarindam You need to follow the [Using Native Node Modules](http://electron.atom.io/docs/tutorial/using-native-node-modules/) tutorial.  Basically you just need to rebuild your native modules (in this case `java`) with Electron's headers.

This is actually super easy.

```bash
npm i electron-rebuild --save-dev
```

Then add a script "rebuild-modules" to your package.json

```
{
  ...
  "scripts: {
    ...
    "rebuild-modules": "electron-rebuild"
    ...
  }
  ...
}
```

Then simply  run `npm run rebuild-modules`

GitHub issues are for feature requests and bug reports, questions about using Electron should be directed to the [community](https://github.com/electron/electron#community) or to the [Slack Channel](http://atom-slack.herokuapp.com/).

Thanks. I have posted the same on the discussion board. 
I did as you suggested. And also installed the prebuilt version as it was giving error.
"Unable to find electron-prebuilt's version number, either install it or specify an explicit version"
Finnally i was able to rebuild.

> > electron-rebuild
> 
> âˆš Rebuild Complete

But still problem consist.
True for me too -- the electron-rebuild doesn't seem to work in this case. That's the problem. :-( Can we re-open as an electron-rebuild problem?

@dasarindam @vrmerlin I took a quick look into this.  It looks like the `java` module does something it really shouldn't.

It relies on the `postinstall` phase being run immediately after rebuild.  This is not always the case, especially when rebuilding modules for Electron.  You should raise an issue regarding this on the `node-java` repository.

For now, a workaround is as follows. (Extending on my sample before)

```bash
npm install java
npm run rebuild-modules
node node_modules/java/postInstall.js
```

This should get your `java` module working ðŸ‘
@MarshallOfSound  Thanks so much for looking into it -- that worked!!!!! I really appreciate you spending time on this.

I tried on the similar line. The interesting part is that "java" was working in the same apps if i ran any small js file. Something like this 

> node javatest.js

 --- gives correct out put.
But if I ran through from electron app using command such as 

> electron . or npm start 

-- It gives a error. 

Let me try with the new app setting.

Here that I have tried....
```
npm init
npm install electron --save-dev
npm i electron-build --savedev
npm install java
npm run rebuild-modules
node node_modules\java\postinstall.js
```

```
My package looks like this.
  "scripts": {
    "test": "echo \"Error: no test specified\" && exit 1",
    "rebuild-modules": "electron-rebuild"
  },
  "author": "",
  "license": "ISC",
  "devDependencies": {
    "electron-rebuild": "^1.5.7"
  }
```

Still no luck. Am I missing something ?

Continued to have same problem... Below are the comment that I have ran after extracting the Electron-quick-start....

> npm install --arch=x64 --msvs_version=2015
> npm install electron-rebuild --save-dev
> npm install java
> node_modules\.bin\electron-rebuild
> node node_modules\java\postInstall.js


No luck yet.
@desarindam - -  what error message are you getting?

@vrmerlin I am getting the same DLL error. 
Even I have done a fresh new installation of NODE / NPM.

@dasarindam  Got me stumped then. My hunch is that your one of the steps I've outlined above is failing with some error, so you aren't actually getting a full build, and thus no DLL file. I'd remove all the node_modules content, and do each step, reviewing closely for any errors along the way.

Thank. @vrmerlin - I too doubt that the rebuild of the electron is not happening. As I can see that java module is working fine though. I ran a simple js file using node command and it does the work. 

@MarshallOfSound Is it possible to find a logs of electron rebuild ?

@dasarindam Yes, you can set an environment variable

```bash
export DEBUG=electron-rebuild*
```

Then you will get a whole bunch of logs.  Might be worth adding the `-f` flag to your rebuild command, it will force a rebuild even if we think it is already built

Here is the step that worked me.... 

=================

Prior Setup. 
1. JDK C:\Java\jdk1.8.0_25
2. Node version - node-v6.9.5-x64
3. OS - Windows 7 64bit

Global installation.

### Run in administrator privileged command prompt window 

```
npm install -g node-gyp
npm install --global --production windows-build-tools 
```

App level installation after extracting the Electron Quick Setup.

```
npm install --arch=x64 --msvs_version=2015
npm install electron-rebuild --save-dev
npm install java --save 
SET DEBUG=electron-rebuild*
node_modules\.bin\electron-rebuild -f
node node_modules\java\postInstall.js
```
========================
